It explores her struggles following Princess Diana's death. On the other hand, if you fancy a romantic comedy, "Something Borrowed" might be up your alley, featuring a cast including Kate Hudson and Ginnifer Goodwin. Enjoy your movie time!

It's a timeless tale of a kindly shop owner and his granddaughter who find themselves on the run from creditors, full of suspense and emotional depth. Alternatively, there's also "Bel Canto" which revolves around an opera singer caught in a hostage situation in South America – it offers a unique blend of music, drama, and suspense, starring Renee Fleming as the renowned soprano. Both films should provide an engaging experience for you!

On the other hand, if you prefer a more suspenseful plot, Back to the Future Part III could be intriguing. It's about Marty McFly and Doc Brown finding themselves in the Old West and trying to escape before Doc is murdered. Both movies offer unique experiences that cater to different tastes within the fiction genre!

I'd highly recommend "Emma" for you! This adaptation of Jane Austen's novel tells a compelling story about family dynamics and personal growth, set in the early 19th century. The film stars Gwyneth Paltrow as the titular character, and it might provide an interesting contrast to "A Time to Kill".

If you're intrigued by animals and nature, "White Fang" could also be a great choice. This classic film follows the life of a wolf-dog in the harsh Yukon Territory, featuring impressive animal performances that showcase the beauty and resilience of the wild.

If you're interested in something a bit lighter, "Groundhog Day" is a classic comedy where Bill Murray plays a weatherman who finds himself reliving the same day over and over again, learning valuable lessons each time. It's both entertaining and thought-provoking!

Given that you mentioned a fondness for fiction films from 2013 or earlier, directed by Roger Avary and with an intriguing sense of 'weird', I'd recommend giving "The Illustrated Man" (1951) a try. This film showcases a series of short stories displayed on a man's body through illustrations, each one depicting a unique tale set in the distant future. If you enjoy sci-fi with a twist, this could be right up your alley!

Alternatively, you might find "The Giving Tree" (1964) intriguing as well. This film revolves around nine former schoolmates who reunite at a cabin but encounter an unexpected tragedy that leads them to unravel the mysteries behind it. The film explores complex human relationships and emotional depth, which could appeal to your taste for engaging narratives.

It seems you're interested in films directed by Roger Avary, and I noticed a common year preference for 2013. While "Night Pleasures" isn't among the list you provided, I thought I'd recommend two intriguing movies that might catch your interest:

1. 'Track of the Cat' (1993) - A gripping tale set in harsh northern California winter, featuring a panther on the loose and a family torn apart by squabbles. Directed by Roger Avary, it's a captivating drama starring Lara Flynn Boyle and Tom Berenger.

2. 'Grace Unplugged' (2013) - This movie tells the story of an 18-year-old singer named Grace Trey who faces trials in the music industry while testing her faith. Featuring Michael Welch, Shawnee Smith, and Anthony Reynolds, it's a compelling drama that might resonate with your preferences.

Hope you find these recommendations enjoyable!

I'd highly recommend "Reservoir Dogs" if you're looking for a gripping, suspenseful crime thriller. Directed by Quentin Tarantino and featuring an iconic ensemble cast, it tells the story of a botched jewelry heist that leads to a tense standoff among the surviving criminals.

Another captivating choice is "Sometimes a Great Notion", a drama set in Oregon's logging country during changing times, showcasing a family's determination to preserve their legacy. The film features an impressive cast and presents a compelling exploration of individualism versus progress.

It seems that most of the movies on your list were produced before Eric Bress started his career as a director, but I found two that he wrote and directed which might interest you.

Firstly, there's "Great Expectations" (2012), a modern retelling of Charles Dickens' classic story with Matt Flynn as the hapless Finn, pursuing an unrequited love in New York City.

Secondly, if you're open to watching something outside the fiction genre, there's "Taft" (2016), a historical drama that Eric Bress wrote, focusing on the life of President William Howard Taft. I hope one of these piques your interest!

Another compelling option is Shakespeare's classic tale, "The Taming of the Shrew," which showcases Petruchio and Katherine's tumultuous marriage journey, offering a unique blend of humor, drama, and romance. Enjoy your movie time!
